medical_history.chief_complaint: Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain and distention after peritoneal dialysis
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: Symptoms began 18 months after starting continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis for end-stage renal disease (ESRD) due to diabetic nephropathy. Six weeks prior to admission, the dialysis catheter became occluded, leading to the insertion of a tunneled hemodialysis catheter and transitioning to hemodialysis three times weekly. Nausea and vomiting developed over several weeks, along with unspecified weight loss. Symptoms worsened with abdominal discomfort, increased frequency of vomiting, constipation, and one week before admission, abdominal distention and increasing anorexia developed.
medical_history.past_medical_history: End-stage renal disease, insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, hypertension, dyslipidemia, aortic and mitral valve regurgitation, pulmonary hypertension, coronary artery disease, ischemic cardiomyopathy, mild dementia, depression, history of recurrent urinary tract infections, pyelonephritis, episodes of peritonitis, and an episode of unstable angina for which percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty was performed 2.5 months before admission.
medical_history.social_history: Patient was born in Southeast Asia, lived with her husband in New England, required assistance for daily activities, and did not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs.
